title: Kelly's Home - Six-Year Absence Rule (Full Exemption)

scenario_info.name: Home Rented During Absence - Within 6 Years
scenario_info.description: Kelly bought her main residence on 1 March 2015 and moved in immediately, living there until 1 December 2019 before moving interstate for work. She rented out her home while working interstate for nearly 5 years. She moved back into her main residence on 1 November 2024. This was her only property and she chose to treat it as her main residence during her absence.
key_points: Kelly lived in the property from March 2015 to December 2019 (4.75 years)
Property rented out during absence: December 2019 to November 2024 (nearly 5 years)
Rental period is within the 6-year absence limit
Only property owned - chose to treat as main residence during absence
applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule (income-producing property)
Property must have been established as main residence first
Absence period for income-producing use can extend up to 6 years
If she moves interstate again after re-establishing main residence, another 6-year period is available

property_history.description: Moved in immediately - established as main residence
Property rented out during interstate work assignment
Kelly returns and moves back into her main residence
Kelly decides to sell after returning

properties.notes: Kelly's only property. Six-year absence rule applies as rental period (4 years 11 months) is within 6-year limit. Full main residence exemption applies to entire gain.

user_query: I moved interstate for work and rented out my only home for nearly 5 years before moving back. I then sold the property 7 months after returning. What is my CGT liability?
